statute_info.statute_citation: Ala. Code § 36-12-40 (as amended by Senate Bill 270, 2024)

key_provisions.response_time: 10 business days to acknowledge, 15 business days to respond (extendable by 15 days)

cross_references: Senate Bill 270 (2024) - significant amendment adding response timeframes
validation_metadata.validator_notes: 2024 amendment creates first statutory response timeframes in Alabama history

key_provisions.fees: Charges for searching/copying exceeding 5 person-hours; fee relief available
key_provisions.exemptions: Personnel records, criminal justice info, consumer protection investigations
key_provisions.enforcement: Administrative appeals within 60 working days of denial

cross_references: 2 AAC 96.370 and 2 AAC 96.470 for fee relief
validation_metadata.validator_notes: Comprehensive statutory framework with detailed regulations

key_provisions.response_time: No specific statutory deadline - reasonable access during business hours
key_provisions.fees: Reasonable fees for copying and reproduction; advance payment may be required
key_provisions.exemptions: Various statutory exemptions referenced but not enumerated in primary statute

cross_references: Title 39 - Public Records, Printing and Notices
validation_metadata.validator_notes: Limited response time specificity in statute

statute_info.statute_citation: Ark. Code Ann. §§ 25-19-101 et seq., particularly § 25-19-105(e)

key_provisions.fees: Actual costs of reproduction plus mailing expenses only

validation_metadata.validator_notes: One of the strongest FOIA laws in the country per official sources

key_provisions.response_time: 3 business days (extendable for 7 additional days under extenuating circumstances)
key_provisions.fees: Research and retrieval fees regulated by statute
key_provisions.exemptions: Statutory presumption in favor of disclosure with specific exemptions

validation_metadata.validator_notes: Recent legislative activity but current law remains at 3 business days

key_provisions.response_time: No specific statutory deadline found - reasonable time standard
key_provisions.exemptions: Various statutory exemptions throughout Connecticut law
key_provisions.enforcement: Freedom of Information Commission with 60-day appeal deadline

cross_references: Legislative study of state agency response times ongoing
validation_metadata.validator_notes: Website access issues prevented full verification

key_provisions.response_time: 15 business days (extendable with good faith estimate)
key_provisions.fees: First 20 pages free, $0.10/page thereafter, $1.00 additional for color
key_provisions.exemptions: Personnel files, trade secrets, investigatory files, criminal records
key_provisions.enforcement: Court review within 60 days, attorney fees available

validation_metadata.validator_notes: Comprehensive statute with clear fee structure

key_provisions.fees: Reasonable copying and administrative fees per O.C.G.A. § 50-18-71(c)

key_provisions.response_time: No specific deadline found in available sources

validation_metadata.validator_notes: Website access restricted - unable to verify full provisions

key_provisions.response_time: 3 working days for residents, 21 days for non-residents (10/35 days if more time needed)
key_provisions.fees: First 2 hours labor and 100 pages free for residents
key_provisions.enforcement: Deemed denied if no response within timeframe

challenges_encountered: Some state websites have access restrictions (403 errors)
PDF documents often have encoding issues
Response time requirements vary significantly between states
methodology_refinements: Focus on official attorney general websites for FOIA guidance
Cross-reference with legislative websites for recent amendments
Use multiple search terms for different state terminology
next_steps: Continue with Connecticut, Delaware, Georgia, Hawaii, Idaho
Develop standardized data extraction approach for remaining 39 jurisdictions
Validate information against official statute databases
